Posts.Content: Ray...you're better off than I was going in. One core positive? PSA under 7... you're golden (so to speak) Now keep your mental health on the high road. Fight it..get in there and mentally and spiritually confront this shit. Prostrate cancer is so common in us guys and when caught early...tooth extraction is more painful. I never took a pain pill after I got home from the hospital...got a full bottle sitting on a shelf. I'm continent right off the get go after catheter out. Although havent tested the "away from home and have to pee real bad" scenario yet. You're gonna be fine...I know it. Jeff
Posts.Title: Path report clear....my story..

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 jefft: Thank you for sharing that wonderful news. It will go a long way toward helping others who find themselves in similar circumstances. I agree that the DaVinci machine has brought this disease to a level where it allows patients to experience the modern advances of science without the fear of so many who don't want to undergo the rigors of open surgery. Even more remarkable (at least to me) are the benefits rendered by the PSA test. The PSA led me to surgery. The PSA found the cancer when it returned and allowed me to proceed with salvage radiation. So, it may have saved my life twice. Whenever I'm in the company of guys over 50 who are friends or relatives, I beseech them to get annual PSA tests. Some never heard of the PSA and that's unfortunate because this is a disease that is almost always curable with early treatment. And the people on that government panel who want to save money and eliminate the PSA because it "may" lead to unnecessary treatment and unwanted side effects can go pound sand up their kazoo. They claim that only one life is saved for each PSA test, which I think is a horrible underestimate. What they fail to mention - even if you accept their numbers - is that for every one million PSA tests, a thousand lives are saved. If ANY test can save a thousand lives, that's a good thing, right? Again, congrats. Jim Yeah Jim...anything the gov can do to cut costs...especially medical costs..they will do. Look where medical science related to prostrate cancer has come in the last 10 years...it saved my life...period. In ten more years it will be saving thousands of lives ... The naysayers are motivated by mis-information and personal agendas. Lets hope the medical community can prove PSA scores are essential to prostrate health and do save lives. We are here to attest to it. Jeff
Posts.Title: Path report clear....my story..

Posts.Content: I was one too.... a newbie freshly diagnosed. Fear took over...I've got cancer. I'm screwed. I'm 59..starting doing the recommended screenings at 50 ...colonoscopy..siegmoid oscopy..blood tests .. everything fine til PSA went to 9.7 and biopsy scheduled. 5 out of 10 pins come back hot. I'm so screwed. Drank to level things out. Did a will. Did a little mid life crisis kinda shit. Worried too much. Didnt give modern science a chance. March 3 went in for the RP. It sucks yeah..but gotta get through it. Catheter is there..whatever. Best part is when you're actually under anesthetic and dont have to feel. But then...we have the post op appointment 7-10 days later with path report. I was mentally ready for salvage radiation. Then the good news. I'm clean... Found out today..TODAY! that i am clean from cancer. My doctors words.."couldnt have asked for a better result" I fucking cried. Had the Davinci S-i.. yes..the best machine on earth. Today I am joyous and want all you with surgery ahead to rest a little easier...dont go off the deep end. Let modern medical science do its thing. But keep clinging to the things that have suddenly become important to you. Tell your loved ones to get screened and tested. My prostate was three freaking times its normal size (will post bio later). Today I rejoice.. and you will too. Jeff
Posts.Title: Path report clear....my story..

Posts.Content: was my digestive track coming back to life after citric cleanse, almost 6 hours of anethesia knocking them out, three days no food and getting tossed around during surgery. I had THE worst sharp cramps and pain when I started introducing water and soft food back into them...they were not ready. I had to ball up my fists and massage my sides to try to work out the cramps.. The incisions and prostrate removal pain was little to none. Never used the oxcy/tylenol after getting home. The whole thing is largely mental... so man up and take control... J

Posts.Title: The worst physical pain for me related to RP..

Posts.Content: Prostrate seems to always have most viewers ....we are a force to be reckoned with ! Trying to share the site with my 32 yr old nephew who is fighting brain tumors and getting proton therapy. He's had two surgeries and is chasing it around... He drives 360 miles a day from central washington to Seattles U of W Medical Center...believed to be one of the only two hospitals with proton. It it doesnt work he wont see his son go to high school.
Posts.Title: Wow..104 viewing...record since I've been here...

Posts.Content: Well my health insurer is Kaiser HMO out here on the west coast. I will probably have to use their surgeons. Hoping for a trifecta anyway.
Posts.Title: Any more room in here...got the word today.

Posts.Content: I'm still kind of numb but did some research prior to getting todays new that I too have PC and want to join the fray. Got some reading up to do and probably several visits with the Udoc to get ducks in a row. A lot of you are very well versed and maybe over-educated about it. I've been through trouble before...and what I remember is I read myself into a frenzy. Not going to do that this time. In a nutshell without specific dates and times and where the moon was at the time..Im 58. I went from normal 3's PSA to a whopping 9.8 within a year or so during the last couple years. Did one biopsy..bingo (10 stabs with the sword) to find 5 of them had between 5 and 20% cancer cells. Doc says its T-1C and Gleason 6... terminology that I'm sure you all know and that now is permanently in my mental hard drive. Doc says treatable and curable... thinking Ill go with removal and let chips fall where they may. Long as I dont pee my pants too much I'll be ok since sex with my girlfriend is not a strong part of our relationship. Now all those commercials about Cialis and V are going to mean something.. Glad there is a place like this to vent and share the journey..
Posts.Title: Any more room in here...got the word today.

Posts.Title: Any more room in here...got the word today.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Hi Jeff, With regrets about your diagnosis, I welcome you to the Prostate Cancer Forum, which is where I just moved your post to. You will get a lot more attention in here. Yes, your T1 Gleason 6 diagnosis does refer to a curable case of PC. Since you are thinking about surgery, the trick is to be sure that the surgeon is top notch. Whether it is open or da Vinci, you'll want to make sure that the doctor has performed a minimum of 300 of them. There is a long learning curve involved. If your doctor is highly competent, incontinence should NOT be an issue for you after recovery is complete. Without reading yourself into another frenzy, you might still consider the 3rd edition of the "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer," by Dr Pat Walsh. Huge amounts of info there. Wishing you the best! Chuck so how do i go about finding out from non-bias medical professionals who is the best??

Posts.Content: Whats up with us... are we just normal me...getting our prostate taken out or taken care of? We seem to hog the broadband here....
Posts.Title: 81 viewers..more than any other forum..?

Posts.Content: Whats up with us... are we just normal me...getting our prostate taken out or taken care of? We seem to hog the broadband here....
Posts.Title: 81 viewers..more than any other forum..?

Posts.Content: I miss sex already..with the main sail at full mast. Whats the waiting period after RP for trying the pump? The low dose of Sildenafil has been causing something down there...a fullness once in a while..(turtle comes out of shell)... gotta wait 2 more weeks to increase dose to 50mg from 25mg...should I just not worry about it right now?
Posts.Title: How long after surgery does one need to wait to try the pump?

Posts.Content: Its a good club...and one of the best sources of cancer info for all. We all wish things were different..but its assumed you are here cause of PCa. How bout we just say "glad you're here", "stick with us, you'll learn a lot", "we'll help you through this" When I logged in and got the sorry shit it was a negative feeling...lets turn that around. maybe a sticky...?
Posts.Title: Why dont we all stop saying "sorry you have to join our club"

Posts.Content: I think we're lucky to have you as the moderator and you said just what I wanted to hear....rock on Chuck!
Posts.Title: PSA in the 9's G6 ... more cancer later?

Posts.Content: Been reading lots of posts...and I know there's a lot of "we wont know til we know" that goes on with all cancers...but who here had a radical robotic..then because PSA was near 10....had post op high PSA indicating there was other cancer in the body somewhere unassociated with prostrate..?? Reason I'm asking is I havent been an angel during my 58 years...alcohol..smoking.. If I've got 10 years to live why go through surgery if lung cancer will take me earlier...keeping it real. Jeff
Posts.Title: PSA in the 9's G6 ... more cancer later?

Posts.Content: I think we're lucky to have you as the moderator and you said just what I wanted to hear....rock on Chuck!
Posts.Title: PSA in the 9's G6 ... more cancer later?

Posts.Content: Thanks Chuck and Southsider...man...I get responses here quicker than Match.com !! No Southsider...I have nothing else (medical condtions) going on right now besides PC...I only started smoking after my bitch wife divorced me in 1998...about a half pack a day.. Alcohol...I was a hard drinker on a sporadic basis...not every day..or every week for that matter. But I've read so many posts where the person's PSA was like 4...or 5....and they came back with cancer later.. I see the Udoc whos going into my insides tomorrow..he's going to get an earful.

Posts.Title: PSA in the 9's G6 ... more cancer later?

Posts.Content: Is this too good to be true? I was expecting a small flood and major dribbling... but so far I am totally continent. Can hold it...feel it coming on..and nothing feels better than peeing after catheter out. Havent yet tested the "minutes from a toilet and major pee coming on" situation yet. Read mostly incontinent situations here in the forums... any of you have good continence right off the bat. Now what am I going to do with a box of 40 Depends from Costco? lol. I am blessed I guess. Now if I can achieve wood at some time down the road I'll have the trifecta ... clean path, continence and wood. I'll certainly take two out of three at this point. Keep your chin up prostrate bros. Good things do happen. Jeff T
Posts.Title: Continent immediately following catheter removal... perplexed.

Posts.Content: I have decided to have radical unless somebody can make a convincing argument otherwise...but...I have a herniated navel... I'm afraid when the fill my abdomen full of CO2 my navel and whats trying to protrude out of it will blow. My first post biopsy appt is Monday and I will bring this up with Udoc...wonder if they can do both radical and fix my button at same time..... I'm not obese or way out of shape... so if theres a resident doc on this forum maybe some help here? Jeff
Posts.Title: Herniated navel complications during surgery

Posts.Content: First PSA test was <0.05 or what my uro doc said as "virtually undectable" Am I in??
